content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Diabetes Self-Management Training Act of 2007". Congress finds that diabetes is a major public health threat in the US, with millions affected and increasing prevalence. Diabetes self-management training is crucial for patients to effectively manage their condition, provided by certified educators. Diabetes self-management training, provided by certified educators, helps patients develop skills to manage their condition effectively and reduce risks. Lifestyle changes have been shown to significantly decrease the risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Studies conducted by the National Institutes of Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention showed that lifestyle changes reduced the risk of developing type 2 diabetes by 58%. This intervention was particularly effective for individuals aged 60 and older, with a 71% reduction in diabetes development. Certified diabetes educators help patients control their diabetes and improve their health status. Lifestyle changes taught by these educators lead to better glycemic control and reduced complications from diabetes, with the potential for preventing serious medical complications by up to 90% for blindness, 85% for amputations, and 50% for heart disease and stroke. Certified diabetes educators play a crucial role in helping patients control their diabetes and improve their health. Evidence suggests that with proper medical treatment and active self-management, the prevention of serious complications from diabetes can be as high as 90% for blindness, 85% for amputations, and 50% for heart disease and stroke. There are over 20,000 diabetes educators in the US, most of whom are certified by the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators. Certification requires specific health care credentials, professional practice experience, passing a national exam, and periodic renewal. Certified diabetes educators, licensed by a State as health professionals, must have a minimum number of hours and years of experience in diabetes self-management training. They are required to pass a national examination and renew their credentials periodically. These educators are uniquely qualified to provide diabetes self-management training under the Medicare program. Certified diabetes educators are recognized as certified providers for Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. Certified diabetes educators are individuals licensed or registered by the state as healthcare professionals specializing in teaching individuals with diabetes to manage their condition. They must be certified by a recognized certifying body, such as the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators. Certified diabetes educators must be certified by a recognized certifying body, such as the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators, which is authorized to grant certification for diabetes educators in the United States. The National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators meets certification requirements for individuals in specified health care professions, including professional practice experience in diabetes self-management training, completion of a national certification examination, and periodic renewal of certification status. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to identify barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes in accessing self-management training services. A report on the study will be submitted to Congress within one year. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations for outreach methods. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress on a study regarding barriers for Medicare beneficiaries accessing diabetes self-management training services. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations for effective outreach methods to educate primary care physicians and the public about the benefits of diabetes self-management training. Healthcare Research and Quality will report to Congress on recommendations for diabetes outpatient self-management training services. The amendments will apply to services provided six months after the enactment of the Act.
